Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: gold, gòld, and gółd

English

[edit]

Etymology 1

[edit]
English Wikipedia has an article on:
Gold (surname)
Wikipedia

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (UK) IPA(key): /ɡəʊld/
  • (US) IPA(key): /ɡoʊld/
  • Homophone: gold
  • Rhymes: -əʊld

Proper noun

[edit]

Gold (plural Golds)

  1. An English surname originating as an occupation for a goldsmith or a rich man.

Etymology 2

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

Gold (plural Golds)

  1. A member of the Goldi or Nanai people.
Translations
[edit]
member of the Goldi people
  • Chinese: 赫哲人
  • Manchu: ᡥᡝᠵᡝ (heje)
  • Russian: нанаец (ru) m (nanajec), нанайка (ru) f (nanajka)

German

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German golt, from Old High German gold, from Proto-West Germanic *golþ, from Proto-Germanic *gulþą.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ɡɔlt/
  • Audio (Austria):(file)
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)

Noun

[edit]

Gold n (strong, genitive Goldes or Golds, no plural)

  1. gold (chemical element, Au)
    Bronze, Silber und Gold habe ich nie gewollt. ― I never wanted bronze, silver and gold (medals).

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Gold [sg-only, neuter, strong]
singular
indef. def. noun
nominative ein das Gold
genitive eines des Goldes, Golds
dative einem dem Gold, Golde1
accusative ein das Gold

1Now rare, see notes.

Coordinate terms

[edit]
  • (Chemical Element): Previous: Platin. Next: Quecksilber

German Low German

[edit]
Low German Wikipedia has an article on:
Gold
Wikipedia nds
Chemical element
Au
Previous: Platin (Pt)
Next: Quecksülver (Hg)

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • Guld, Goolt

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle Low German gôlt, from Old Saxon gōld, from Proto-West Germanic *golþ, from Proto-Germanic *gulþą. More at gold.

Noun

[edit]

Gold n (no plural)

  1. gold (chemical element, Au)
  2. gold (color)
  3. (heraldry) or

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Goldfever
  • Goldküst
  • Goldmedaille
  • Goldsmölten
  • Narrengold (Pyrit, Swevelkies)
  • Noordisch Gold

See also

[edit]
  • cheemsch Element
  • Eddelmetall

References

[edit]
  • Der neue SASS: Plattdeutsches Wörterbuch, Plattdeutsch - Hochdeutsch, Hochdeutsch - Plattdeutsch. Plattdeutsche Rechtschreibung, sixth revised edition (2011, →ISBN, Wachholtz Verlag, Neumünster)

Hunsrik

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Old High German gold, from Proto-West Germanic *golþ, from Proto-Germanic *gulþą.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈkolt/
  • Rhymes: -olt
  • Syllabification: Gold

Noun

[edit]

Gold n

  1. gold
    Das is aus Gold gemach waar.
    This was made of gold.

See also

[edit]
Symbol Pt Au Ag Fe Al Sn Cu
metal Platin Gold Silver Eise Aluminium Zinn Kupper

Further reading

[edit]
  • Boll, Piter Kehoma (2021), “Gold”, in Dicionário Hunsriqueano Riograndense–Português, 3rd edition (overall work in Portuguese), Ivoti: Riograndenser Hunsrickisch, page 68

Luxembourgish

[edit]
Chemical element
Au
Previous: Platin (Pt)
Next: Quecksëlwer (Hg)

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German golt, from Old High German gold, from Proto-West Germanic *golþ, from Proto-Germanic *gulþą. Cognate with German Gold, English gold, Dutch goud, Icelandic gull.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ɡolt/

Noun

[edit]

Gold n (uncountable)

  1. gold

Derived terms

[edit]
  • gëllen
  • goldeg

Old English

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ɡold/, [ɡoɫd]

Proper noun

[edit]

Gold m

  1. a male given name

Pennsylvania German

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Compare German Gold, Dutch goud, English gold.

Noun

[edit]

Gold n

  1. gold
